channel.title: Differential Equation & Laplaces on
channel.description: Recent content in Differential Equation & Laplaces on

item.title: Differential Equation & Laplace
item.description: ➤ Dashboard Lessons ➤ Lesson 1 - Introduction to differential equations ➤ Lesson 2 - Seperating variables ➤ Lesson 3 - Boundary values ➤ Lesson 4 - Linear first order homogeneous differential equation ➤ Lesson 5 - Linear first order non-homogeneous differential equation ➤ Lesson 6 - Linear higher-order non-homogeneous differential equation ➤ Lesson 7 - Linear higher-order differential equations ➤ Lesson 8 - Applications of differential equations ➤ Lesson 9 - Laplace transform ➤ Lesson 10 - Laplace transform properties ➤ Lesson 11 - Inverse Laplace transform ➤ Lesson 12 - Laplace transform and differential equations ➤ Lesson 13 - System of differential equations

item.title: Lesson 1
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Equation An equation is an expression of a relationship between quantities, also called variables or unknowns.

item.title: Lesson 10
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Linearity property Let $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ and $\mathcal{L}(g(t)) = G(s)$ Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be constants.

item.title: Lesson 11
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Inverse Laplace Transform If $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ then $\mathcal{L}^{-1}(F(s)) = f(t)$ Shift in s

item.title: Lesson 12
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Properties until now Let $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ and $\mathcal{L}(g(t)) = G(s)$ and $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are constants.

item.title: Lesson 13
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Properties so far Let $\mathcal{L}(f(t)) = F(s)$ and $\mathcal{L}(g(t)) = G(s)$ $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are constants.

item.title: Lesson 2
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Serparating variables A differential equation has two variables. For some differential equations it is possible to separate the variables: on the left-hand-side there is just the dependent and on the right-hand-side just the independent variable.

item.title: Lesson 3
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Direction field A differential equation can be visualised in a sol called direction field.

item.title: Lesson 4
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Linear first-order homogenous differential equations General form: $\frac{dx}{dt} + p(t)\cdot x = 0$

item.title: Lesson 5
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Non homogenous differential equation $$\frac{dx}{dt} + p(t)\cdot x = r(t)$$ If $r(t) \neq 0$ then this linear differential equation is not homogenous.

item.title: Lesson 6
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Linear higher-order differential equations General form: $$a_{n} \frac{d^{n}x}{dt^{x}} + a_{n-1} \frac{d^{n-1}x}{dt^{n-1}}+\cdots + a_{1}\frac{dx}{dt}+a_{0}x = r(t)$$ if $r(t) = 0$ then the differential equation is homogeneous.

item.title: Lesson 7
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Boundary values If we want to solve a specific second-order differential equation, two boundary values are necessary.

item.title: Lesson 8
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace WIP Lesson 7 ⮜ … ⮞ Lesson 9

item.title: Lesson 9
item.description: ➤ Dashboard ➤ Differential Equation & Laplace Why Laplace? The laplace transform can be used to slove differential equations and is used extensively in electical engineering.
